titleStmt.title: Running head: NEURAL CORRELATES OF CONSTRUAL IN ECONOMIC DECISIONS 1 Neurological and Behavioural Correlates of Construal in Economic Decision-Making Under Cognitive Load

affiliation.orgName: Department of Psychology, School of Social Sciences, Humanities and Law

analytic.title: Running head: NEURAL CORRELATES OF CONSTRUAL IN ECONOMIC DECISIONS 1 Neurological and Behavioural Correlates of Construal in Economic Decision-Making Under Cognitive Load

application.desc: GROBID - A machine learning software for extracting information from scholarly documents

abstract.p: The results data and related information for this paper can be accessed through the Open Science Framework: Wilson, C. J. (2024). Neurological and behavioural correlates of construal and self-control in economic decision-making under cognitive load. osf.io/k75mv NEURAL CORRELATES OF CONSTRUAL IN ECONOMIC DECISIONS

div.p: Construal theory (Trope & Liberman, 2003) suggests that people adopt different levels of psychological distance from future events, which leads them to consider the events more abstractly, often framed as the "Why?" perspective (high-level construal) or in more detailed terms, often framed as the "How?" perspective (low-level construal). It is argued that construal level has a range of consequences regarding how we evaluate, predict and behave in relation to future events, depending on the psychological distance we adopt from those events (Trope & Liberman, 2010).
Construal effects have been demonstrated across a range of domains, including:

language (Divjak et al., 2020); visual perception (Nussinson et al., 2019;Van Kerckhove et al., 2015); physical position and proximity (Holland et al., 2004;Slepian et al., 2015); temporality (Liberman et al., 1998;Trope & Liberman, 2003) and implicit association (Bar-Anan et al., 2006). However, two areas where construal effects have been particularly prevalent in are the overlapping topics of ris k (Lermer et al., 2015(Lermer et al., , 2016Raue et al., 2015) and economic behaviour (Leiser et al., 2008;Okdie et al., 2016).

It has been demonstrated that construal affects both how risk is perceived (Wakslak et al., 2009) and decisions under risk. For example, there is evidence to suggest that high level construal leads to higher levels of risk-taking (Lermer et al., 2015) and risk-seeking . Correspondingly, it has been shown that low level construal can lead to lower levels of risk-taking, which is argued to be caused by more detailed consideration of probable outcomes and more focus on the negatives (Lermer et al., 2015).

However, exact effects of low and high construal on economic behaviour are more complex than this. Some of this is related to the how temporality influences construal (Liberman et al., 1998). For example, Rudzinska-Wojciechowska(Rudzinska-Wojciechowska, 2017) found that high construal was associated with higher levels of delayed gratification and increased propensity towards better long-term financial behaviour. However, this is consistent with findings that high construal mindsets are associated with events further in the future (Trope & Liberman, 2003) and a willingness to delay gains(H.-X. Chen & He, 2012), where psychologically closer (low construal) events increase perceptions of risk (Chandran & Menon, 2004). One factor that is known to influence the effects of construal is the framing of risks as potential losses or gains. For example, Sagristano et al. (Sagristano et al., 2002) found that high temporal construal might serve to attenuate focus on potential gains, while low temporal construal promotes prevention of potential losses.

There has also been some variation to the findings in relation to low/high effects. For example, Okdie et al., (Okdie et al., 2016) found that in one study, high construal led participants to avoid decks in the Iowa Gambling Task (IGT(Brevers et al., 2013))that were more risky in one study and in a second study, the opposite was true. While they suggest the discrepancy might be cause by the different methods used to induce construal in each study, it is worth noting that Lermer et al. (Lermer et al., 2015) also alternated between the same two approaches (concrete/abstract priming vs. why/how priming) and did not find a difference in results.

Another contributing factor to this complexity is that construal interacts with other processes that can affect risk perception and economic decision making. Two of the most important constructs that have been shown to interact with construal in relation to economic decisions are cognitive load (Deck & Jahedi, 2015) and self-control (Fujita, 2008). Cognitive load affects many dimensions of economic decision-making, including: delay discounting (Martinelli et al., 2017); framing effects ; anchoring effects (Blankenship et al., 2008); acceptance of fair offers (Harris et al., 2020) and risk-taking (Pabst, Schoofs, et al., 2013) -the general consensus is that reduction in available cognitive resource leads to more impulsive, poorer economic decisions (Adamkovič & Martončik, 2017). Cognitive load has shown to interact with how construal affects decision-making.

Both Körner & Volk (2014) and Fukukura et al. (2013) found that high construal led to improved decision-making under load, through the adoption of more overarching rulesets or general processing (as opposed to more specific rules or specific information processing).

While these studies are not focused on economic decisions, it could be argued that this the inverse of the aforementioned effect (e.g., Lermer et al. 2015) that high construal is associated with more risky (i.e., poorer) decisions. Recent work by Ren et al., (2023) with children in poverty (which has been found to impair executive functioning and increase cognitive load (Adamkovič & Martončik, 2017;de Bruijn & Antonides, 2022;Haushofer & Fehr, 2014;Mani et al., 2013Mani et al., , 2020 found that construal level interacted with executive functioning and cognitive capacity, such that high construal led to better decision making, but only for the poverty cohort. These findings suggest that further exploration of the interaction between cognitive load and construal on economic decisions would be useful.

Construal level also appears to moderate the relationship between and individual's self-control and their economic behaviour (Fujita et al., 2019). Schmeichel et al.,(2011) suggest that this could be because low construal increases self-control for tasks that are focused on more immediate response inhibition and high construal for more delay focused control. At the same time, the exact relationship between self-control and construal in economic decisions is unclear.

Moreover, many recent studies which examine the effect of self-control conceptualised self-control as a limited cognitive resource that, when depleted leads to low self-control in subsequent decisions (Baumeister, 2014;Baumeister et al., 2008;Dou et al., 2014;Fischer et al., 2012). Some research found that this lead to riskier decision-making (N. Freeman & Muraven, 2010), while others found the opposite (Unger & Stahlberg, 2011).
There is ongoing debate about this theory (Friese et al., 2019;Hagger et al., 2016;Inzlicht et al., 2014;Scherbaum et al., 2018;Vohs et al., 2021) which is outside the remit of this paper.

However, there is ambiguity around whether response inhibition tasks (e.g., Stroop, Go/NoGo) commonly used in such studies ((S. M. Freeman & Aron, 2016;Kelley et al., 2019;Luethi et al., 2016) are depleting self-control resource or, as they are conceptualised in many other studies (e.g., (Dekkers et al., 2017;Morra et al., 2018;Terentjeviene et al., 2018;Zihisire Muke et al., 2021), increasing cognitive/executive load. Given this, there is merit in separating how self-control and cognitive load are operationalised (Sekścińska et al., 2021), so we can better understand if/how they interact with construal.

Finally, work examining the neurological evidence for construal 1 found a neural signature for temporal distance(S. Lee et al., 2022;Stillman et al., 2017), while Stillman et al.(Stillman et al., 2020) and Gilead et al., (Gilead et al., 2014) showed differential patterns of activation for high versus low construal using fMRI. However, there has been comparatively little work on the neurological correlates of construal in the context of economic decisionmaking, particularly in the prefrontal cortex, which is involved in the cognitive aspects of economic decision-making (Çakir et al., 2018;Gathmann et al., 2014;Holper, ten Brincke, et al., 2014;Li et al., 2012;Wanniarachchi et al., 2020), and is active specifically when there is a risk-based choice (Mohr et al., 2010). Moreover, because neural activation in economic decision-making varies depending on a range of psychological factors, including related concepts such as motivation emotional state and risk preference, it is there is reason to hypothesise the same could be true of construal (Bechara & Damasio, 2005;Kable & Levy, 1 There has been much work examining neurological correlates of "self/other construal" which is distinct from the high/low construal of Construal Level Theory that is the focus of the current paper.

2015; Luethi et al., 2016;Malecek & Schonberg, 2015). While the aforementioned studies found neural markers for different construal levels generally, if construal is a factor in driving economic decisions, the it is likely we should see neurological indicators of construal during decision-making which is potentially related to the decision choice that is made (Niu et al., 2023) and the expected value of the decision involved (Holper, ten Brincke, et al., 2014).

The current research aims to enhance our understanding of how construal interacts with cognitive load and self-control to affect economic decision-making and to identify neural correlates of construal in an economic decision-making context. In two multi-phase experimental studies, cognitive load is induced before participants are exposed to a gambling task. During the task, immediately preceding each gambling decision, participants are prompted with either low or high construal (or no construal control) exercises using a "Why/How" task paradigm (Lermer et al., 2016;Okdie et al., 2016). Self-control is also measured (Lindner et al., 2015). In Experiment 2, cognitive load and construal tasks are enhanced and financial literacy (Allgood & Walstad, 2016;Brown, 2010;Fernandes et al., 2014) and subjective numeracy (Dunn & Ashton-James, 2008;Fagerlin et al., 2007;Skagerlund et al., 2018;Zikmund-Fisher et al., 2007) are added as covariates. Neurological activation in the lateral prefrontal cortex (LPFC) is measured using functional near infrared spectroscopy (fNIRS: Çakir et al., 2018;Cazzell et al., 2012;Holper, ten Brincke, et al., 2014; during both pre-decision construal stage and decisionmaking stages of each trial.

Based on previous research, it was hypothesised that there would be differences in risk-taking behaviour under cognitive load between Low, High and No Construal conditions in both experiments. However, the direction of the differences between High and Low Construal are inconsistent in previous findings. In Experiment 2, it was predicted that we would see neurological indicators of construal pre-decision and during decision-making, as well as neurological indicators of an interaction between construal and expected value of decisions, as well as construal and decision choice.

div.head: Design
div.p: Experiment 1 employed a 1-way independent experimental design. The betweengroups independent variable was construal level, with 3 conditions (High Construal, Low Construal and No Construal condition), which manipulated the type of cue that was presented during the coin-toss task. Self-control was measured using the Brief Self-control Scale (BSCS (Lindner et al., 2015;Tangney et al., 2004)). The binary outcome variable was if participants chose to gamble during the coin-toss task (Gamble / No Gamble).
Participants 76 participants were recruited to take part in the study. 75 participants completed the experiment (Male = 11, Female = 64, Other/Non-binary = 0; Mean age = 24.66, SD = 9.15).
Participants were recruited through a research participation scheme in the Dept. of Psychology at Teesside University and received research participation credits for taking part.

The sample size was based on a prospective power analysis using simulation for mixed effects models(DeBruine & Barr, 2019), with simulation using the paramtest (Hughes, 2017) package in R(R Core Team, 2023) based on a null effect probability of 0.5 for the coin toss outcome and 0.8 for an effect leading to an odds ratio of 4 (5000 sims, p = 0.05, power = 0.8). Figure 1 shows the sequence of Experiment 1. The experiment was programmed using the jsPsych JavaScript framework for running behavioural experiments (Leeuw et al., 2023) and administered in a web browser using a local JATOS back-end (Lange et al., 2015). The study took place in a university computer lab using a Dell Optiplex PC with HP EliteDisplay E232 monitor @ 1920px * 1080px (60hz).

div.head: Cognitive Load Task.
div.p: A Stroop task was used to induce cognitive load (Morra et al., 2018;Zihisire Muke et al., 2021). The task contained 32 trials, with 50% congruent and 50% non-congruent.

div.head: Construal Cues.
div.p: To manipulate level of construal, a cue task was adapted from Brevers et al., (2018) Three versions of the cue task were employed: Low Construal, High Construal and a No Construal Condition. In both the Low and High Construal conditions, participants were presented with a cue related to financial decision-making (e.g. "Making sure I have enough money to pay my bills on time": see Appendix A for list of prompts), with an additional prompt that was varied depending on Construal condition, based on the "Why/How" construal tasks (Lermer et al., 2016;Okdie et al., 2016). In the Low Construal Condition participants were prompted to consider the specific steps necessary to achieve a particular financial goal. In the High Construal condition, participants were prompted to consider why they might want to achieve a particular financial goal. The No Construal condition employed a version of the cue task where statements did not mention construal or finances in any way and prompted participants to think about unrelated scenarios, similar to the control condition employed by (Brevers et al., 2018).

div.head: Coin-Toss Trials.
div.p: The economic decision task used was a block of coin-toss trials (see Figure 2), previously employed by Carr & Steele(2010) and Brevers et al.(2018). Participants started the task with a set number of credits. They were presented with 20 coin-toss trials which had a 50% chance of winning and a 50% chance of losing. The trials comprised 5 possible expected values (0, 2.5, 5, 7.5 and 10), which were presented in random order. During the trial, participants were asked if they would like to flip the coin or not. If the decision was to gamble, the coin toss took place, and the win/loss outcome was presented to participants on screen (see Figure 2).

div.head: Coin-Toss Lottery.
div.p: To help incentivise realistic responding during the coin toss trials (Brevers et al., 2018;Camrer & Hogarth, 1999;Kamenica, 2012;Lee, 2007), participants were told that they could be selected at random (probability of selection = 0.2) to play the coin-toss task for real to win research participation credits. It was explained that if they were selected, one of their coin tosses in this task would be selected later. If the participant was selected, one of the coin-toss trials from the previous task was then selected. If the participant had previously chosen to gamble on the selected trial, they would be presented with a coin-toss trial in which they started out with a bonus of 20 credits and could win or lose an amount based on the expected value of the selected trial. If the participant was not selected for the lottery, then they would be notified and continue to the next phase of the study.

div.head: Self-Control Measure.
div.p: Self-control was measured using BSCS (Lindner, Nagy, and Retelsdorf, 2015). This measure has shown across several studies to have good internal consistency, test-retest stability, and construct validity (Brevers et al., 2017;Chiesi et al., 2020;Liang et al., 2022;Ozaki et al., 2016).

div.head: Participant Response Accuracy and Attention Checks.
div.p: Several checks were implemented during the study to ensure the validity of participant responses. Firstly, in the cognitive load task, participants were required to achieve an accuracy score of greater than 70% within 3 attempts. If they did not achieve this level of accuracy, the study ended and they were remunerated but not considered to have completed the study, and therefore not included in any analysis. Secondly, participants responses were screened upon completion based on 2 attention-check questions that were asked during the study and required specific responses. These were added to the demographic questionnaire before the experiment began and while completing the Brief Self-control Scale at the end of the study (For example, "It is important to pay attention in this study. Please tick 'Rarely/Never'"). If participants failed 1 of these checks, they were not considered to have completed the study satisfactorily, and therefore not included in any analysis.

div.head: Results Experiment 1 Analytic Approach
div.p: Responses in the coin-toss task were binary (Gamble / No Gamble). Data were analysed using random intercept mixed effects logistic models, with participant as the random grouping factor (lme4: Bates et al., 2020). Post-hoc comparisons between conditions were performed using estimated marginal means with Tukey adjusted multiple comparisons (Lenth, 2016).

div.head: Participant Attention and Accuracy
div.p: Of the 76 participants originally recruited for the study, 1 participant did not obtain sufficient accuracy in the Stroop task within three attempts and so did not progress to the end of the study. Analysis was conducted on the 75 participants who completed the study. Mean accuracy in the Stage 1 task was 95% (sd = 1). All participants answered all attention check questions correctly.

div.head: Does Expected Value Predict Likelihood of Gambling?
div.p: This model showed that Expected Value of trials predicted likelihood of gambling (Table 1: AIC= 433.5, χ2(4) = 441.47, p < 0.001) with post-hoc comparisons showing higher likelihood of gambling in trials with higher expected values (see Table 2).

div.head: Does Construal Predict Likelihood of Gambling?
div.p: Construal was added to the previous model (i.e., Table 1) and improved model fit (Table 3: AIC= 6.6, χ2(2) = 10.60, p < 0.01) with Construal also being a significant predictor of likelihood of gambling. Post-hoc comparisons (Table 4) of the Construal conditions showed significantly higher likelihood of gambling in the No Construal (compared to the High Construal Condition).

div.head: Does Self-Control Predict Likelihood of Gambling?
div.p: Self-control (BSCS score) was added to the previous model but was not found to be a significant predictor (p > 0.05) and did not significantly improve model fit (p > 0.05).

div.head: Experiment 2
div.p: The results of Experiment 1 showed that under cognitive load, Low Construal predicted lower likelihood of gambling in the coin-toss task compared to the No Construal condition. The goal of Experiment 2 was to see if any neurological indicators of construal could be identified in either the pre-decision cueing phase, where participants were prompted to adopt the high or low construal mindset (Gilead et al., 2014), or during the decision itself , depending on the participant choice (Niu et al., 2023) or the expected value of the decision (Holper, ten Brincke, et al., 2014).

Neurological markers of specific cognitive processes during decision-making are often difficult to isolate, as they are impacted by individual differences, such as motivation (Westbrook & Braver, 2015). For this reason, some additional elements were added to the cognitive load and construal phases of the study. To enhance the cognitive load effect, a Go/NoGo task was added (Gomez et al., 2007). Go/NoGo tasks have been used to elicit specific activation related to response inhibition (Mostofsky et al., 2003;Wright et al., 2014).

However, there is evidence that in most contexts they might be inducing a more general cognitive load (Criaud & Boulinguez, 2013;Kato et al., 2009), which can be exacerbated when task switching is involved (Swainson et al., 2003).

Matching fNIRS data to brain structure is affected by optode placement relative to each individual (Tsuzuki & Dan, 2014), which can make within-groups designs preferrable for certain task designs (Emerson et al., 2022). A within-groups design was employed in Experiment 2, to reinforce switching of construal perspectives between blocks, an additional task was added, based on Krastev et al., (2020), which asked participants to complete a written task to explicitly confirm the adoption of a particular construal perspective.

Finally, while self-control was not found to predict decision-making in Experiment 1, it was retained to examine if there were any neurological indicators of self-control during decision-making (Mouloua & Shaw, 2023). In addition, it was decided to examine two other variables that contribute to economic decisions: Financial Literacy and Subjective Numeracy.

Financial Literacy (Allgood & Walstad, 2016;Brown, 2010;Fernandes et al., 2014) is known to influence short-and long-term financial decisions (Henager & Cude, 2017;Schüler et al., 2019) by impacting financial planning and behaviour (Goyal & Kumar, 2021;Lusardi & Mitchell, 2014. However, literature also indicates that numeracy is an important component of financial literacy (Bruin & Slovic, 2021;Darriet et al., 2020;Skagerlund et al., 2018) and that it contributes to some constructs within financial literacy such as the perception and comprehension of risk (Gigerenzer & Edwards, 2003;Petrova et al., 2014).

Previous work has shown a neural a signature for risk perception related to numeracy (Vogel et al., 2016) and for financial literacy (Duke Han et al., 2014;Sunderaraman et al., 2022). However, much of the previous work on neural correlates of financial literacy has focused on cognitive decline in old age (Han et al., 2013(Han et al., , 2016Lamar et al., 2023;Nowrangi et al., 2022;Duke Han et al., 2014;Sunderaraman et al., 2022). Dickert et al., (Dickert et al., 2011) fond a link between numeracy and pro-social behaviour and suggested that future work should examine the potential role of construal. However, to the author's knowledge there have not been any previous studies which have examined the interaction between financial literacy or subjective numeracy and construal level theory in the context of economic decision-making. As such, the current study aimed to examine if there was any relationship between construal and financial literacy in this context.

div.head: Material and Methods Experiment 2
div.p: Experiment 2 retained the methodological features of the previous experiment, with some additions. Here the changes from Experiment 1 are outlined and explained.

div.head: Design
div.p: This experiment employed a 1-way within-groups experimental design, with the same independent variable and conditions as Experiment 1. As with Experiment 1, the outcome variable was whether or not participants chose to gamble during the coin-toss task (Gamble / No Gamble) and self-control was measured using the Brief Self-control Scale (BSCS: Lindner et al., 2015). Additionally, Financial Literacy and Subjective Numeracy were measured using questionnaires (Fagerlin et al., 2007;Fernandes et al., 2014).

Participants 26 participants were recruited to the study (Male = 8, Female = 17, Other/Non-binary = 1; Mean age = 26.28, SD = 10.2), based on a power analysis using simulation for mixed effects models (DeBruine & Barr, 2019), based on the coefficients observed in Experiment 1 for the Construal conditions (nsims = 5000, p = 0.05, power = 0.8). Sample size calculations in relation to fNIRS is less clear due to variability of effects (Yücel et al., 2021). However, the sample was considered comparable to other studies using fNIRS to examine cognition and decision-making (n = 10 -24, e.g., Aghajani et al., 2017;T. Chen et al., 2021;Emerson et al., 2022;Holper, ten Brincke, et al., 2014). Three participants were excluded from the study prior to data analysis, due to fNIRS recording issues which led to incomplete data. Figure 3 shows the Experiment 2 sequence. The tasks and measures that were retained from Experiment 1 were not modified. However, the following were added:

div.head: Cognitive Load Tasks.
div.p: A Go/NoGo task was added the cognitive load phase of the experiment. This was the visual form of the task (Gomez et al., 2007) for which one stimulus (i.e., a blue circle) required participants to respond using the spacebar and the other stimulus (i.e., an orange circle) required participants to refrain from responding. Stimulus presentation times were randomised between 800ms and 1000ms with a 70/30 probability ratio of Go to NoGo trials (Bokura et al., 2001).

div.head: Construal Statement Task.
div.p: Before each block in the coin-toss task, Construal level was manipulated using a 'Why' task and a 'How' task adapted from Krastev et al., (2020) and Freitas et al., (2004).

Before the High Construal block, participants were asked provide "four reasons why people save money". Before the Low Construal block, participants were asked to provide "four reasons how people save money". Before the No Construal block, participants were asked to "write down four objects that are in the room you are currently in". Participants typed their responses into a textbox via the computer keyboard.

div.head: Financial Literacy Measure.
div.p: Financial Literacy was measured using a questionnaire adapted from Fernandes et al, (2014) which comprises 13 items representing a reliable unidimensional construct of financial literacy, which correlated strongly with constructs such as numeracy, confidence in financial information search, planning for money-short term, being spendthrift, preference for numerical information, attitude/concern for money, self-efficacy and delayed gratification (see Fernandes et al., 2014 for details).

div.head: Subjective Numeracy Measure.
div.p: Subjective Numeracy was measured using the Subjective Numeracy Scale, developed by Fagerlin et al., (2007) which comprises 8 items related to respondents' preference for information in numerical formats and their confidence in completing basic arithmetic calculations. Higher scores on the scale have been shown to predict both risk comprehension and calculation of utility (Zikmund-Fisher et al., 2007).

div.head: Neurological Activiation Measure.
div.p: Activation in the LPFC was measured using fNIRS with the FNIR400 system (Biopac Preprocessing was conducted using gsignal (Boxtel et al., 2022) package for signal filtering and the pracma (Borchers, 2022) package for moving average smoothing and polynomial detrending. Raw intensity signals of 730nm and 650nm near-infrared were converted to HbO and HbR via the modified Beer-Lamber law (DPF = 6), relative to a 30sec baseline that was taken at the beginning of the experiment. The preprocessing pipeline to remove artifacts from the fNIRS data comprised a 10hz lowpass fir filter to reduce the effects of heart beat, respiration and other high frequency interference, a 1.5s moving average filter to smooth the signal, and a low order of 6 polynomial to remove linear and non-linear trends (Dashtestani et al., 2019).

There are a variety of approaches commonly used to analyse fNIRS studies and consensus has not been reached on a single preferred method (Tak & Ye, 2014;von Lühmann et al., 2020). However, recent published work has suggested that mixed-effects models offer some advantages in analysing fNIRS as they reduce aggregation of data (DeBruine & Barr, 2019) and allow specification and comparison of a model structures to better fit the data (Gokalp Yavuz & Cakar, 2023). The current study employed mixed effects models (lme4:

Bates et al., 2020)) with participants as a random intercept factor, and compares both nested (participant:region) and non-nested models, using the model that is a better fit for the data based on AIC, BIC, Log likelihood and Deviance statistics. In all cases, non-nested models with participants as a random intercept were a better fit for the data, so these models were used. Post-hoc comparisons were conducted using Tukey corrected estimated marginal means (Lenth et al., 2024). Models with interactions were also tested and are included with post-hoc comparisons if significant interactions were present. A hierarchical model-building approach was used, with AIC values reported (compared to Null or previous models) for comparison purposes.

For hypothesis testing, the current study used HbO data, which has been shown to be more sensitive to changes in cerebral blood flow and less noisy than HbR (Homae et al., 2007;Niu et al., 2023). Raw HbO data were mean scaled (Lin et al., 2021), which can aid model fitting. Analysis was conducted to examine cerebral hemodynamic changes based on Brodmann's area (Strotzer, 2009), which is inferred from the placement of fNIRS optodes, so that mean values in each Brodmann's area were calculated for each participant, for each trial.

div.head: Behavioural Results: Do Construal, Expected Value or Self-Control Predict Likelihood of Gambling?
div.p: To examine if the behavioural results of Experiment 2 replicated Experiment 1, a random intercept mixed effects logistic model with participant as the random grouping factor was fitted with the behavioural data with Construal, Expected Value and Self-control (BSCS Score) as predictors (Table 5: AIC = -283.65, 2 (7) = 297.65, p < 0.001) . The model showed that Expected Value and Self-control were significant predictors of likelihood of gambling, with higher likelihood of gambling in trials with higher expected values. Construal was not a significant predictor of likelihood of gambling in this model (p > 0.05).

div.head: Are There any Neurological Indicators (HbO Level) of Construal During the Pre-Decision Construal Cue Period?
div.p: Activation during pre-decision phase was measured as the mean HbO level for each trial during the 30-second window prior to gambling decision being presented, where participants were presented with construal cues (see Figure 2). Models of cortical activation (HbO Level) during the pre-decision phase were fitted in models with Construal and Brodmann's Area as predictors. The results (Table 6: AIC = -916, 2 (5) = 116.35, p < 0.001) indicated that activation in areas BA44 and BA45, as well as High and Low Construal trials, predicted HbO level during this pre-decision phase. Post-hoc contrasts ( Table 7 and Table 8) showed significant differences in HbO levels between Brodmann's Areas but not between Construal.

div.head: Does Construal Predict HbO Levels During Decisions?
div.p: To examine neurological activation during the gambling decisions, a window from 3 seconds pre-decision to 5 seconds post-decision was selected (e.g., Niu et al., 2023) for each trial to account for lag in hemodynamic responding and mean HbO was calculated (Figure 4).

div.head: Models of activation during the decision-making phase were fitted with Construal and
div.p: Brodmann's Area ( AIC = -114, 2 (5) = 124.64, p < 0.01) as predictors. The results (Table 9) indicated that activation in areas BA44 and BA45, as well as High and Low Construal Blocks, predicted HbO level during decision making. In addition, post-hoc contrasts (Table 10 and Table 11) showed significant differences in activation between Brodmann's Areas (highest activation in BA10 and BA46), as well as Construal Blocks (higher activation in No Construal relative to Low and High).

div.head: Do Expected Value or Decision (Gamble/No Gamble) Predict HbO Levels During
Decisions?
div.p: To examine the role of Expected Value of gambling decision and Gambling Choice, these were added as predictors to the previous model. Comparisons of model fit indicated that adding Expected Value and Gambling Choice improved model fit ( AIC = -6.5, 2 (12) = 13.45, p < 0.01). Consistent with the earlier model (i.e., Table 9), the results (Table 12) indicated that activation in areas BA44 and BA45 predicted HbO level during decision making (see Figure 5). In addition, there was an interaction between Construal, participants' Gambling Choice and Expected Value. Post-hoc tests of the interaction term (Table 13) indicate significantly higher levels of HbO in the No Construal block (compared to both High and Low Construal blocks), for Expected Values 0, 2.5 and 5, during the No Gamble trials.
There were also significantly higher levels of HbO in the High Construal block (compared to Low Construal), for Expected Values 0, 2.5 and 5, for Gamble trials.

div.head: Do Self-Control, Financial-Literacy or Subjective Numeracy Predict HbO Levels
During Decisions?
div.p: To examine the role of Self-control, Subjective Numeracy and Financial Literacy, each of these scores were added individually to the previous model (i.e., Table 12). The Self-control model (Table 14: AIC = -1000.4, 2 (6) = 1025.4, p < 0.01) showed that BSCS score interacted with Construal in predicting HbO level, with post-hoc tests of the interaction (Table 15) The Financial Literacy Model, (Table 16: AIC = -46.9, 2 (6) =58.87, p < 0.01) showed that Financial Literacy score interacted with Construal in predicting HbO level. Posthoc tests of the interaction (Table 17) The Subjective Numeracy model (Table 18) showed that Subjective Numeracy score interacted with Construal and Gambling Choice in predicting HbO level. Post-hoc tests of the interaction (Table 19)

div.head: Discussion
div.p: Previous research has demonstrated a complex relationship between construal and self-control in their effects on economic decisions under cognitive load. In particular, there was conflicting evidence about whether or not low-or high-construal should lead to riskier decisions; some ambiguity about how self-control or cognitive load interact with construal due to conceptual overlap; and a need for further evidence on neurological indicators of construal during decision-making. Across two experiments, current paper aimed to discern how construal under cognitive load affected risk-taking in an economic decision task and to identify neurological indicators of construal prior to decision-making, during decisionmaking, and related to the expected value of a decision or the decision choice. There are several novel findings which add to our understanding of how construal under cognitive load affects risky economic decisions, while also raising questions that need to be explored in future research.

div.head: The Effects of Construal on Economic Decisions.
div.p: Experiment 1 demonstrated the effects of construal mindsets on economic decisions under cognitive load. The results showed that participants in the High Construal condition were less likely to gamble than the No Construal condition. Notably, this finding appears to contradict previous findings on how construal is likely to affect risk-taking behaviour (Lermer et al., 2016;Raue et al., 2015;Sagristano et al., 2002). However, it is consistent with Körner & Volk (2014) who found that when cognitive capacity is reduced, the effects of construal on moral decisions were reversed. Moreover, it is consistent with findings which suggest that under cognitive load, high construal can lead to "better" decisions. For example, Fukrkura et al., (2013) suggest that abstraction is a benefit to decision-making under cognitive load, because it allows organisation of information in more general terms rather than specifics (gist processing), reducing the mental burden. In addition, Ren et al., (Yi Ren et al., 2023) also suggested that effects of increased cognitive load on decision-making that are caused by the effects of ongoing poverty, could be reduced through the use of high construal interventions, which appears to improve performance on executive functioning tasks. To explain the effect, we might consider that increased cognitive load increases risk aversion (Deck & Jahedi, 2015) and that high construal leads to a more general (Fukukura et al., 2013), goal-focused (Schmeichel et al., 2011) mindset. It is not illogical then, that under cognitive load, the strategy adopted for achieving the goal was through loss minimisation, rather than maximising gains.

While the testing these theoretical explanations is outside the scope of this paper, the findings of Experiment 1 provide further evidence for construal effects under load that are the inverse of what would normally be predicted. Further work is needed to directly compare how high/low cognitive load conditions interact with construal in an economic decision context, as well as teasing out whether the theory put forward by (Fukukura et al., 2013) might explain the effects observed.

It is important to note that the results of Experiment 2 did not replicate the behavioural findings of Experiment 1. One interpretation of this result is to consider that previous research has also shown some inconsistency with replicating effects related to cognitive load (Ball et al., 2023) and construal (Okdie et al., 2016) on economic decisionmaking. However, it must be acknowledged that the results could be due to lack of sufficient power for Experiment 2, based on an unintended overestimation of the true effect of construal based on Experiment 1 (Bartoš et al., 2023). This is less of an issue for the fNIRS data in Experiment 2, as there are more fNIRS data points and the use of mixed effects modelling removed the need for over-aggregation of the data, helping with statistical power (Gemignani et al., 2023;Kumle et al., 2021;Wiley & Rapp, 2019). As such, the most appropriate approach is that no conclusions are drawn about the effects of construal on behaviour from Experiment 2. Nevertheless, the results of Experiment 2 do show an effect for expected value on likelihood of gambling, consistent with Experiment 1, which shows participants were responding consistently across both experiments and is useful for interpreting the neurological data.

div.head: Neurological Indicators of Construal During Economic Decisions.
div.p: Experiment 2 allowed examination of the neurological indicators of construal under cognitive load in the LPFC at several timepoints in the decision process. The first timepoint is before the decision is presented, when participants engaged in the "Why/How" task to elicit either a high, low (or no construal) mindset. This timepoint is comparable to studies such as Stillman et al.,(2020) and Gilead et al.,(2014) who found evidence of activation in the ventromedial pre-frontal cortex (using fMRI and EPI, respectively) during various types of construal elicitation. In the current study, we find a general effect for construal on LPFC activation, with lower overall levels of activation (highest levels in BA10 and BA46) associated with both low and high construal compared to no construal trials. However, there was no difference in activation between low and high construal trials at this point.

This finding is interesting because previous evidence for construal effects (specifically, level of abstraction effects) have been associated with dorsomedial and ventromedial prefrontal cortex (PFC), the anterior superior temporal sulcus (STS), the temporoparietal junction (TPJ) and the posterior cingulate cortex (PCC), rather than the LPFC (Spunt et al., 2016). However, Spunt et al., (2016) did not find any "Why/How" specific effects in these areas, while Gilead et al., (2014) found evidence of a trend, supported at a lower significance threshold. The current study found an effect for "Why/How" construal in the LPFC, albeit with differences in activation between Construal/No Construal during the pre-decision construal elicitation timepoint. A potential explanation for this effect could be construal elicitation moderating the cognitive load effects from earlier tasks, where LPFC activation tends to increase with cognitive load (Agbangla et al., 2022;Fishburn et al., 2014) and construal might moderate LPFC activation related to load. This could be a general neural marker for construal that is consistent with the shift in focus towards response control that is said to occur with adoption of construal mindset (Schmeichel et al., 2011), albeit with no discernible difference between high and low construal at this point.

Notably, at the timepoint when decisions were made, there were differences in LPFC activation levels between low and high construal. This extends the previous work that had found inconsistent effects of "Why/How" construal manipulation which had focused on the MPFC and PCC but had not examined economic/risk-based decisions (Gilead et al., 2014;Spunt et al., 2016). The results of the current work also show that LPFC activation during decision-making was dependent on the decision that was made (Gamble/No Gamble) and expected value of the outcome. Activation in the LPFC related to risk (Bembich et al., 2014;Liu et al., 2024) and expected value has been observed previously, as has activation related to decisions themselves (Holper, ten Brincke, et al., 2014). However, the higher activation for high (relative to low) construal for gamble decisions is significant because it suggests that a high construal mindset can promote sensitivity to risk, given fact that these differences were:

1. Only present when risks were taken (i.e., gamble trials) and 2. present in trials with expected values from 0-5 (riskier decisions) but not in trials with the highest expected values of 7.5 and 10 (higher reward relative to risk). Taken together with the results of Experiment 1, where high construal reduced likelihood of risk-taking, we see a pattern that is different from Lermer et al., (2015Lermer et al., ( , 2016 -who found that high construal mindset was associated with greater risk-taking -and more consistent with the inverse effect that some studies have suggested is indicative of construal under cognitive load (Fukukura et al., 2013;Körner & Volk, 2014;Yi Ren et al., 2023). As such, the current studies could be the first to show behavioural and neurological evidence of the how the effect of construal on risk-sensitivity might change under cognitive load. However, further work is needed to test this theory.
Neurological Indicators of the Interaction Between Self-Control and Construal.

Self-control was examined across both Experiment 1 (relative to behavioural responses) and Experiment 2 (relative to behavioural and neurological responses). In Experiment 1, self-control was not related to risk-taking behaviour, whereas in Experiment 2, higher levels of self-control predicted lower likelihood of gambling. Moreover, self-control effects were present when construal effects were not, and vice versa. Taken together, the results paint a complex picture of the role of self-control in economic risk-taking. On the one hand, the results of Experiment 2 are similar to Sekścińska et al.,(2021), who found that selfcontrol (measured on the same scale as the current studies) negatively predicted risk-taking in a lottery-like task. Others have also found this relationship (Wang et al., 2019). As such, there is not an immediately obvious explanation for why this relationship did not occur in Experiment 1, and it is worth examining this further in future research.

On the other hand, Sekścińska et al.,(2021) also note the point that was mentioned in the introduction of this paper -that the general inconsistency of findings in relation to how self-control is associated with risk-taking, is somewhat confounded by how the now disputed "strength model" of self-control that was employed by many studies (Baumeister, 2014;Baumeister et al., 2008;Dou et al., 2014;Fischer et al., 2012;N. Freeman & Muraven, 2010;Unger & Stahlberg, 2011), uses cognitive load/exertion tasks as a proxy of impaired selfcontrol. In this regard, the contrasting behavioural results of Experiment 1 and 2 with respect to self-control suggest that while potentially related, the relationship between self-control and risk-taking behaviour was distinct from any cognitive exertion effect (Koppel et al., 2019).

The neurological from Experiment 2 showed an interesting interaction between construal and self-control, where lower levels of self-control were associated with lower LPFC activation during economic decisions in high and low construal (compared to no construal trials). In contrast, high levels of self-control were associated with higher LPFC activation during economic decisions in high and low construal (compared to no construal trials). These findings extend previous work showing PFC involvement in self-control (Schüler et al., 2019), and more specifically, impulse control (Shenhav et al., 2017), especially when cognitive demands are high (Wolff et al., 2019). Moreover, they suggest that that a potential neurological marker of the interplay between self-control and construal that has been observed previously at a behavioural response level (Schmeichel et al., 2011).

However, while these studies have usually found distinct patterns of behaviour associated with high and low construal (Fujita et al., 2006), here we find an neurological indicator for construal generally.

div.head: Financial-Literacy and Subjective Numeracy Predict Neurological Activation
During Economic Decisions.
div.p: In Experiment 2, financial literacy was found to interact with construal in predicting LPFC activation during decisions. Low levels of financial literacy were associated with higher levels of activation in the no construal trials (relative to high and low construal) and in the high construal trials (relative to low construal). In contrast, high levels of financial literacy were associated with the inverse effect. Much of the previous work on neural correlates of financial literacy has focused on cognitive decline in old age (Han et al., 2013(Han et al., , 2016Lamar et al., 2023;Nowrangi et al., 2022;S. Duke Han et al., 2014;Sunderaraman et al., 2022) and there has been no work (to the author's knowledge) that has examined the interaction between financial literacy and construal in the context of economic decisionmaking. To the extent that we can relate the current findings to previous research, the results could indicate that there was higher motivation to engage with the construal approaches for those with higher financial literacy (Luethi et al., 2016). In addition, the differential patterns of activation between high and low construal at different levels of financial literacy is somewhat analogous to findings by Campos and Costa (Campos & Costa, 2021) who suggest that indebtedness amongst low-income consumers is linked to the adoption of a highconstrual (abstract) mindset. However, further work is recommended to tease apart the relationship between financial literacy and construal level in the context of economic decisions, in order to draw more substantive conclusions.

Interestingly, subjective numeracy interacted with construal and gambling decisions in Experiment 2. Low subjective numeracy was associated with higher HbO levels for low construal compared to high construal. However, when subjective numeracy was high, the inverse was true: lower HbO levels for low construal compared to high construal.

Importantly, for trials where participants gambled, the same trend was evident, but the difference in activation between high and low construal was much more pronounced, especially for participants with low subjective numeracy. Previous work has suggested that numeracy influences neurological activation of risk perception in a health context (Vogel et al., 2016) and there is an established link between numeracy and financial behaviour (Bruin & Slovic, 2021;Skagerlund et al., 2018). These results support those previous findings, as well as testing Dickert et al.,'s (2011) suggestion that numeracy might interact with construal in a financial decision context, by showing the interaction between construal and subjective numeracy in LPFC activation, as well as how the difference in activation is related to the decision that is made.

div.head: Conclusions, Limitations and Future Research.
div.p: The results of the two experiments presented in the current paper produced several interesting findings that add to our understanding of how construal affects economic decision-making under cognitive load. Experiment 1 found an effect of construal mindsets on economic decisions under cognitive load. Experiment 2 showed that neurological activation in the LPFC during these decisions was linked to construal level, but that construal could promote risk sensitivity since differences in activation between construal levels were only present when riskier decisions were taken. Experiment 2 found self-control to be a predictor of both behaviour and neurological activation, where it interacted with construal level. In addition, subjective numeracy and financial literacy were both found to interact with construal level in predicting neurological activation, with low numeracy levels indicating larger differences in activation between high and low construal during risk-taking.

Nevertheless, the studies have limitations that could be addressed in future work to confirm or expand upon the current findings. The difference in behavioural results between Experiments has already been discussed and while this has also been observed in other studies (Ball et al., 2023;Okdie et al., 2016), it is something that will need to be addressed through replication.

Another potential limitation that a reader might perceive is that the design of the current studies was such that we did not include any "no cognitive load" control condition, as this would have allowed us to separate out the roles of construal and cognitive load more cleanly. However, we feel this was a valid approach for the current studies, since the goal of the research was to compare the effects of construal levels (which did include a control condition) on decision-making under load, based on previous work which had suggested an interaction in both lab and real-world contexts (Fukukura et al., 2013;Körner & Volk, 2014;Yi Ren et al., 2023). As such, we wanted to use that work as the starting point for the current studies and employed tasks that have been long-established for inducing cognitive load in experimental settings (Criaud & Boulinguez, 2013;Kato et al., 2009;Morra et al., 2018;Zihisire Muke et al., 2021). Indeed, the behavioural results in Experiment 1 confirmed previous findings that high and low construal affect decisions differently under cognitive load in almost the opposite way to what we might usually expect (Fukukura et al., 2013;Körner & Volk, 2014;Lermer et al., 2015;Raue et al., 2015). This was also supported by neurological data in Experiment 2, which suggested that high construal under load might be linked to greater risk-sensitivity. In future work, we need to tease apart the cognitive load and construal interaction at both cognitive and neurological levels.

Further work is also needed to examine the role of self-control, with Experiment 2 suggesting an interaction between construal and self-control in both behavioural and neurological responses which is consistent with some previous findings (Fujita et al., 2006;Schmeichel et al., 2011;Schüler et al., 2019;Wolff et al., 2019). Finally, more work will be needed to explore the roles of numeracy and financial literacy, with the neurological data from Experiment 2 suggesting that they both interact with construal during economic decisions.

Systems Inc.). The forehead mounted sensor comprised 16 optodes (4 LEDs and 10 photodetectors). Light was emitted in the 730nm and 850nm wavelengths at a frequency of 2hz. The placement of the sensors was such that Brodmann's Area 10 (Fpz International 10/20 system) corresponded with the midpoint of the sensor band between channels 9 and 7(Fairclough et al., 2018). The optode placement corresponds to Brodmann's areas 10,44,45 and 46 in the LPFC (seeMcKendrick et al., p.6 (2020). Signal quality was first assessed to identify weak (below 700) and saturated (reaching 4000) nir signals using a combination of visual inspection and computational checks (min/max/mean signal strength, frequency and timing of threshold breaches) with data from any low quality channels being removed from subsequent analysis(Orihuela-Espina et al., 2010).

, indicating higher HbO levels in the No Construal block (compared to Low and High Construal blocks) when BSCS scores are low (-1SD below the mean) and lower HbO levels in the No Construal block (compared to Low and High Construal blocks) when BSCS scores are high (+1SD above the mean).

indicated significantly higher levels of HbO activation in the No Construal block (compared to Low and High Construal blocks) and in the High Construal (compared to Low Construal blocks) when Financial Literacy levels were low (Mean -1SD). There were also higher HbO levels in Control (compared to Low Construal blocks) when Financial Literacy was average (Mean). When Financial Literacy levels were high (Mean + 1SD) the pattern inverted, with significantly lower levels of HbO activation in the No Construal block (compared to Low and High Construal blocks) and in the High Construal (compared to Low Construal blocks).

indicated that when Subjective Numeracy was low (Mean -1 SD), there were significantly lower levels of HbO activation in the No Construal block (compared to Low Construal block) and in the High Construal (compared to Low Construal blocks). This was true for both Gamble and No Gamble Trials. When Subjective Numeracy levels were average (Mean), there were significantly higher levels of activation in the No Construal block (compared to High and Low Construal blocks) in No Gamble trials, but these differences were not present in Gamble trials. When Subjective Numeracy was high (Mean + 1SD) there were significantly higher levels of activation in the No Construal block (compared to High and Low Construal blocks) in No Gamble trials. However, in Gamble trials, there were significantly higher levels of activation in Control (compared to Low Construal block) and High (Compared to Low Construal block).
